channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-5938] After Multiple Profile Deployments Fabric Container Runs Out of PermGen Space
item.description:
After repeated redeployments of a profile to a Fuse Fabric container, PermGen space is slowly consumed until PermGen is maxed out and an OutOfMemory:PermGen error is thrown and the container becomes unresponsive.

Some space seems to be recovered after each redeployment, but the amound recovered gets progressively smaller until the OOM is thrown.
item.environment: JBoss Fuse 6.2.1 Karaf / Fabric - Reported on Rollup 1 / 090, confirmed on Rollup 2 / 107
item.summary: After Multiple Profile Deployments Fabric Container Runs Out of PermGen Space

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Child log with JDK8 and OOM: Metaspace
Child container redirected.out for JDK 1.8 with -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=384M -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal
Child container fuse.log for JDK 1.8 with -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=384M -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal
Redirected output for karaf std out child container with JDK 1.7 and -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal
Fuse log for child container with OpenJDK 1.7 b91 and -XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal

Only one leak left!

bundle karaf.management.server

this     - value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #12
 
 <- m_wiring     - class: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoaderJava5, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #12
 
  <- <classLoader>     - class: org.apache.karaf.management.RmiRegistryFactory$KarafServerSocketFactory, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoaderJava5 #11
 
   <- <class>     - class: org.apache.karaf.management.RmiRegistryFactory$KarafServerSocketFactory, value: org.apache.karaf.management.RmiRegistryFactory$KarafServerSocketFactory class RmiRegistryFactory$KarafServerSocketFactory
 
    <- ssf     - class: sun.rmi.transport.tcp.TCPEndpoint, value: org.apache.karaf.management.RmiRegistryFactory$KarafServerSocketFactory #1
 
     <- key     - class: java.util.HashMap$Node, value: sun.rmi.transport.tcp.TCPEndpoint #10
 
      <- [12]     - class: java.util.HashMap$Node[], value: java.util.HashMap$Node #23440
 
       <- table     - class: java.util.HashMap, value: java.util.HashMap$Node[] #124
 
        <- localEndpoints (sticky class)     - class: sun.rmi.transport.tcp.TCPEndpoint, value: java.util.HashMap #153

Here's the source code for sun.rmi.transport.tcp.TCPEndpoint:

// TBD: should this be a weak hash table?
 
private static final
 
    Map<TCPEndpoint,LinkedList<TCPEndpoint>> localEndpoints =
 
    new HashMap<>();

the comment doesn't give me a choice - brute force cleaning the cache via reflection inside org.apache.karaf.management.RmiRegistryFactory#destroy - I checked that it removes last CL leak.

I'll of course check more complex scenarios now - with SSH containers, ensemble servers and other profiles.

OK, now I added jboss-fuse-full profile to child container. Here are new suspects:

bundle pax-logging-service:

bundle aries.transaction.manager

this     - value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #125
 
 <- m_wiring     - class: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoaderJava5, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #125
 
  <- <classLoader>     - class: org.objectweb.howl.log.LogBufferManager, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoaderJava5 #129
 
   <- <class> (Java frame)     - class: org.objectweb.howl.log.LogBufferManager, value: org.objectweb.howl.log.LogBufferManager class LogBufferManager

so not that bad after all - maybe it won't be that easy with howl...
See https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/868

https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/pull/869 resolves Jetty memory leak, so only three left:

  • the one with org.objectweb.howl.log.LogBufferManager
  • the one with org.apache.karaf.shell.log.VmLogAppender
  • and guest starring: https://issues.jboss.org/browse/ENTESB-5935?focusedCommentId=13283595&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13283595 (visible after actual http sessions are created)

Leak with org.apache.karaf.shell.log.VmLogAppender is easily solvable with...

log:clear

command.

Roger Hui not bad. Here's my summary for child container:

  Basic info:
 
    Date taken: Wed Aug 24 08:32:35 CEST 2016
 
    File: /data/tmp/child-1-after-create.hprof
 
    File size: 50.3 MB
 
 
 
    Total bytes: 40,261,840
 
    Total classes: 11,919
 
    Total instances: 628,572
 
    Classloaders: 268
 
    GC roots: 3,433
 
    Number of objects pending for finalization: 0
 
 
 
  Environment:
 
    OS: Linux (4.6.6-200.fc23.x86_64)
 
    Architecture: amd64 64bit
 
    Java Home: /opt/java/javase/jdk1.8.0_102-custom/jre
 
    Java Version: 1.8.0-internal
 
    JVM: OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (25.71-b00, mixed mode)
 
    Java Vendor: Oracle Corporation

~600 classloaders for Fuse root container is normal (~70% of them are classloaders related to reflection). For example in my child container I had:

  • 130 instances of sun.reflect.DelegatingClassLoader
  • 112 instances of org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoaderJava5 - this is what we should control as these are bundle classloaders

Duane Hawkins great job!

the good news is that:

  • org.apache.karaf.shell.log.VmLogAppender leak can be fixed by doing "log:cleaar" and it's temporary anyway
  • jgit NLS problem - I fixed it already in 6.3 (no commit yet) by shadowing two little JGit classes
  • sun.rmi.transport.tcp.TCPEndpoint problem - I fixed it in Karaf
  • END_OF_DOCUMENT_ENTITY problem - I fixed it in Karaf - unfortunately - the fix goes to $FUSE_HOME/lib/endorsed/org.apache.karaf.exception-2.4.0.redhat-VERSION.jar, so no HF patch possible...
  • also I don't see problem related to jetty here - there's my PR pending to be merged in jetty 8, but maybe it's not that critical with pax-web 3.2.x

the only new problem which I didn't see before is with org.apache.aries.proxy.impl.interfaces.ProxyClassLoader...

I just saw:

org.ops4j.pax.web.service.jetty.internal.ServerControllerImpl.listeners fixed with https://ops4j1.jira.com/browse/PAXWEB-1011
I'm testing 6.2.1 with Jetty updated to 8.1.20 and relevant PAXWEB fixes I made.
All the leaks under: ENTESB-6025

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
1. Deploy JBoss Fuse 6.2.1 / Karaf (I used Rollup 2 for testing)
2. Create a Fabric with fabric:create --wait-for-provisioning
3. Create a child container
4. Attach a profiler like JVisualVm to the child container process
5. Alternately provision and remove the JBoss Fuse Full profile on the container.
6. Watch the PermGen usage climb in stair-steps until an OOM is thrown

Note: I did see one stop the world GC in which the PermGen dropped considerably, but following that event was able to force the OOM by continuing to redeploy.
